comment_0:
The meaning of this song is explained. It is credited to Lennon/McCartney although it seems Lennon wrote most lyrics.


"I came in and he had this first stanza, which was brilliant: 'I once had a girl, or should I say, she once had me.' That was all he had, no title, no nothing. I said, 'Oh yes, well, ha, we're there.' And it wrote itself. Once you've got the great idea, they do tend to write themselves, providing you know how to write songs. So I picked it up at the second verse, it's a story. It's him trying to pull a bird, it was about an affair. John told Playboy that he hadn't the faintest idea where the title came from but I do. Peter Asher had his room done out in wood, a lot of people were decorating their places in wood. Norwegian wood. It was pine really, cheap pine. But it's not as good a title, Cheap Pine, baby...
So she makes him sleep in the bath and then finally in the last verse I had this idea to set the Norwegian wood on fire as revenge, so we did it very tongue in cheek. She led him on, then said, 'You'd better sleep in the bath'. In our world the guy had to have some sort of revenge. It could have meant I lit a fire to keep myself warm, and wasn't the decor of her house wonderful? But it didn't, it meant I burned the fucking place down as an act of revenge, and then we left it there and went into the instrumental."
Paul McCartney
Many Years From Now, Barry Miles


Norwegian Wood is a fake wood that was used to make cheap furniture. Lennon knew people who were using it in their homes and thought it would make a good title.
There are not many lyrics in this song, but they tell the story of a man who gets invited to a girl's house. When she won't let him into her bed, he sleeps in the tub. When she leaves the next morning, he sets the place on fire. It was one of the first songs Lennon wrote that told a complete story.
comment_1:
REPORTER: 	I'd like to direct this question to messrs. Lennon and McCartney. In a recent article, Time magazine put down pop music. And they referred to "Day Tripper" as being about a prostitute...

PAUL: 	Oh yeah.

REPORTER: 	...and "Norwegian Wood" as being about a lesbian.

PAUL: 	Oh yeah.

REPORTER: 	I just wanted to know what your intent was when you wrote it, and what your feeling is about the Time magazine criticism of the music that is being written today.

PAUL: 	We were just trying to write songs about prostitutes and lesbians, that's all.
comment_2: Norwegian Wood is a type of very cheap pine. It burns quickly. Paul says it was his idea to burn the place down in the song. John says there was no one woman he was thinking about when he wrote this song, but that he was having so many affairs at the time, he wrote it in such a way as to keep his first wife Cynthia from getting suspicious. It has also been suggested that the woman in the song was the actress, Natalie Wood. As an actress, she would need to get up early to be on the movie set. John did meet a number of starlets in Hollywood during their tours, including Jayne Mansfield, but Natalie Wood has never been documented. With John's love for word play, it's plausible he would change "Natalie" to "Norwegian", but I doubt this.
comment_3: this song is so vague because john was having an affair, but since he was married to cynthia at the time, he didnt want her to know.  the sitar is the best part of the song...
comment_4:
This is a clever little song about revenge, which seems odd for the Beatles, but the sly twist makes it more humorous than cruel.  He sets up by saying he once 'had' a girl, meaning he had her where he wanted her, or so he thought.  In fact, it was she who 'had' him, as in yanked his chain.  She made him think he was going to get lucky, but all she really wanted was his company for a few hours.  

So, the girl invites him to her place, and he is expecting to get it on with her.  Instead she prattles on and on until 2 AM, talking about irrelevant things and trying to impress him: "Look at this place, it's made of Norwegian wood.  Isn't it good?"  So he's been waiting all this time for her to put out, but she instead decides it's time for bed because she has to get up early.  She does not invite him to sleep with her (thereby the song hints that they didn't do what he was there expecting to do--have sex); annoyed, he goes off to sleep in the tub, which is no doubt very uncomfortable.  

When he wakes she's gone; she didn't even have the decency to wake him up and say goodbye.  So what does he do?  Burns down her precious Norwegian wood house. :-)
comment_5:
Reading all of these postings I became fascinated - OK obsessed -with all of the interpretations of this song.  I thought I knew what the song was about, but apparently not.  I decided to send out a poll to family and friends (ages 28 through 60) to get their opinions. I asked them 3 questions:
1) Was one person seducing the other, and if so which one?
2) Did they have sex>
3)What does âNorwegian woodâ refer to, and how does it relate to the fire at the end?

Suprisingly enough - with the 15 responses I got as many - maybe more - than are found here.
1) 7 people thought that she was seducing him, 1 thought he was seducing her, the remainder thought it was either mutual or weren't sure.
2)10 thought they did not have sex, while 5 thought they did.
3) 3 people thought he burned furniture in the fireplace, 2 people thought he was smoking marijuana, 2 people though he burned the place down, 4 people thought that that Norwegian wood referred to logs in the fireplace, and 2 people thought the setting was Norway and that it referred to the forest outside.

Despite the relatively few answers to these questions, it resulted in a myriad of combinations, so only a few peoples' interpretations of the song coincided : e.g. she seduced him, they had sex and he threw a table in the fire vs. she seduced him, they didn't have sex and he lit the fire in the morning, vs.....
And interesting point, a couple reserached the song, were surprised by the arson theory, and flat out rejected it. 

As for my own interpretation - - it was similar to azaudâs.  I also feel compelled to discount the arson theories based on the meoldic nature of the tune and the tone of the lyrics. 

Great discussion on everybody's part.

comment_10:
It amazes how complex some interpretations are, when to me the song's meaning is so obvious! Drugs? Lesbian? Oral sex? Arson? Come on! You're reading WAY too much into this song! Here's what it means:
The narrator goes to the girl's apartment, which is furnished with Norwegian furniture (later made famous by brands such as Ikea). This furniture showed that she was cool and modern  -- "hip." The "she once had me" line simply means that in the end she fooled him. The fact that there wasn't a chair simply means that the apartment was sparsely furnished -- not unusual in the style of a young, student-age single woman. He goes home with her, hoping for some physical interaction, and bides his time as they drink wine. But alas, she has only been teasing him, and goes off the bed  by herself after getting his hopes up by saying, "it's time for bed." She leaves him to fend for himself as far as sleeping arrangements are concerned, so he crawls off (probably half-drunk) into the bathroom -- sleeping on the floor or in the tub, I presume. The next morning he wakes up after she has gone off to work, and is angry that she led him on, that she played mind games with him, so he lights a fire (in the fireplace, I assume) using some of her nice Norwegian furniture for firewood. This gives him a little sick pleasure as a sort of revenge for her teasing him -- exactly the sort of thing that an acerbic, cynical John Lennon would do, or would think of doing.
comment_11: of course, number one lesson from this song: BUY A SITAR
comment_12:
Wow. I would have thought that for a song by the Beatles SOMEBODY would have gotten it right by now.  They broke up in something like 1977, right?  Anyhoot here is my take.  "surreal" came closest in my opinion, somewhat informed by talking with songwriters and pro musicians.  No the guy did not burn the effing house down or go around breaking up the furniture and no, nobody got stoned and no its not a secretive coded message about somebody's marriage at the time.  

It's just a song, people. Its a simple song, which works because simplicity is what Lennon and McCartney were good at.  Its about a fairly common for the '70s scenario that involves a sexless would-have-been "one-nighter". If you went to the College of William and Mary you know this sort of thing all too well. 

The girl toys with the guy, who probably was a bit horny, and he really does go off to sleep in a cold, comfortless place, and he wakes up alone and full of bitterness at the lack of resolution of any kind; she does not explain, she just leaves. She got her own emotional payoff, so she is done with him already. 

The "fire" referenced is simply the nature of the guy's feelings relating to anger and frustration. So he makes a fire in the fireplace, probably with peat or coal, to warm himself; not exactly the best conclusion to a failed night of thwarted passion.  The last line is bitter, very bitter, sarcasm with a slight reference to the cheap faux oak furnishings lacking sincerity or depth. Not much to read into it.   There is nothing in the musical progression to suggest anything so violent as breaking up the furniture or burning the house down; the Beatles were not in that sort of space in the late 1960's and neither was pop. Its just a simple song about sexual and emotional and spiritual frustration that goes unrelieved.

comment_26: I think you're all way off (especially 0cool). It sounds to me like this song is about a girl who plays with a guy's feelings... it starts off with the greatest line ever written "I once had a girl, or should I say, she once had me", which implies they were a couple, he was in love with her while she was just playing with him. The bit about the chair implies that she has no need for him, that he doesn't really have a place in her life. Sexual innuendo follows next, and I guess the guy in the song felt just like he needed to cool himself off in the bath. The reference to Norweigan Wood is there because she's a 'bird' that has many 'trees' to choose from. Litting the fire could perhaps imply suicide, or if that Paul quote is correct, that he burnt the house down.. her games having driven him insane and that's how he plots his revenge. I also think this song is definitely vague on purpose.

comment_42:
This song may or may not be John's autobiographical account of certain bizarre exploits with original Beatles bassist Stu Sutcliffe in the early sixties club scene in Germany.

"I once had a girl, or should I say she once had me"
He never had her, but he was "had" or led on by her.

"She showed me her room, isn't it good Norwegian wood?"
Norwegian wood refers to the room itself.

After she says, "It's time for bed," the vocals are interrupted (for the only time in the whole song) by an oddly placed and relatively lengthy musical interlude consisting of George's sitar theme played twice (also for the only time in the whole song).

This is a deliberately clumsy device to manipulate the listener into thinking (for about twenty seconds) that a pop song in 1965 has just made an undisguised reference to casual sex.

This was a time when married couples on TV slept in two beds.

After John makes the same assumption as the listener, the girl rejects him and laughs in his face.
He sleeps in another room, not necessarily in a tub.

In the morning, the girl or "bird" has gone to work, assuming he will either let himself out or stick around for another chance at humiliation.

She is in for a smoldering surprise.

"She asked my to stay and told me sit anywhere, 
So I looked around and I noticed there wasnât a chair"

She knows there's no reasonable place to sit, except on the bed beside her.

"She told me she worked in the morning and started to laugh" 

She's saying "Let's hurry it along;  I haven't got all night."  

She's trying to seduce him, but he's not playing along.  

I hadn't heard about the substitution of "Norwegian Wood" for "knowing she would" until recently, but it makes perfect sense, and reveals what his game is.

There are a lot of slang words for drugs and I suspect "Norwegian Wood" came about after this song rather than informing the lyrics. I have always thought the lyrics strange. We have all been turned down by girls without setting the house on fire. The tone of the whole narrative is realistic up until that (implied) ending.
It is very like imagist poetry - a series of images convey a state of mind.
I also think the music (and the sound of the words rather than their meaning) are better than the lyrics.

comment_58: I'm not up on my Beatles history, but I do feel a personal kinship with all of the songs that John Lennon writes, and this was obviously a Lennon tune.  When I hear the words to this song, I simply imagine the simple but powerful feelings that correspond to each image that's put forth.  The entire song is sung in a kind of flippant and melancholy tone.  This lends emotion to the events taking place and transports me every time to being in the shoes of the man who is doing the narrating.  The emotions that I get are mostly are excitement at getting some tail, but at the same time a feeling of disgust and emptiness that they really don't mean anything to each other at all.  Also, I have the distinct feeling that I'm being used by the chic in the song, and that kind of pisses me off.  It's very significant that once he fucks her he crawls out of the bed and goes to sleep in the bathtub.  He wants to separate himself from the event after it's over, because he's not comfortable with it and really can't stand the chic because she's annoying and presumptious.  "If anybody's going to be doing the using, it's me," he thinks.  I mean, accurately creating this feeling through song is a tremendous accomplishment, regardless of the trivia about who he was banging or which words he was allowed to use or not in conveying it.  Who cares about that tabloid garbage?  Certainly not me or any other intelligent person.

comment_84: c'mon guys.  back away from the herb.  You're overcomplicating the song.  The Beatles themselves said the song was originally "knowing she would" instead of Norwegian Wood.  In British parlance, "bird" is a  slang for a girl that's like "chick".  "And when I awoke, I was alone, this bird had flown.  so i built a fire. isn't it good, knowing she would?"  I.e., ain't it great knowing she'd take off.  It's a provocative song about a hook up.  That's all. (which at the time was risque).  They get to her place, hook up. No chair to sit in, so he sits on the floor until it's time for the hookup (because otherwise he'd have to sit on the bed, the only other place) It's just a hook up, so he goes and sleeps in the bathroom afterwards, instead of sleeping with her, because she's going to be getting up early.  When he wakes up, she's gone already, and he's glad because then he doesn't have to deal with any of the morning after stuff.
comment_85:
John Lennon / Rolling Stone 1979 - "Norwegian Wood was about an affair I was having. I was very careful and paranoid because I didn't want my wife Cyn to know that there was really something going on outside of the household. I'd always had some kind of affair going on, so I was trying to be sophisticated in writing about an affair" 
  Paul McCartney / 1989 - "I added the bit on the end about burning down the house, it was my addition to the song"

i love the sitar in this. it's very amazing.

i think that the song is about this girl leading john on almost, she shows him her room and since she's poor the bed must be made of norwegian wood (which is fancy way of saying cheap pine). and she doesn't have a chair, again alluding to the poor thing.

they must've gotten pretty wasted or something "drinking her wine" and started to do something, but she thought about how she had work in the morning and killed it.

so john got mad and slept in the bath. and when he woke up, she was gone, and because he was still mad, he probably burned her furniture or something.

the slept in the bath part really resonates with me. i remember a long time ago i was sleeping over at my thea's house. it was me, my sister, and her two other nieces.
she got mad at us and told us that if we didn't behave she's separate us and we could all sleep separately, one in one room, one in another, one in her room with her, and one in the bathtub.

i found it incredibly funny at the time, but now it sort of symbolises a sort of estrangement. like, being separated from everything, in the cool unfeeling bathtub.

kind of like john is complaining about how he is estranged from his wife, because he is having an affair, but it's his own fault, because he "crawled off to sleep in the bath." and nobody made him go.

and when he's alone because the girl had to work, he feels stupid and takes his anger out on her house/furniture/whatever, and also this bird has flown could be him realizing he totally screwed over his relationship with cynthia.

but that's just my two cents.
i love this song, anyways.

comment_98:
As I recall, I was still in my teens when I first heard this song & as was my wont I meditated long on the meaning of the lyrics. Eventually it occured to me that John Lennon was prone to write "nonsense" lyrics to produce exactly that effect on the listener - to set their minds to wondering.
 It was also a custom of the Beatles to write "filler" lines while composing. just to keep the lyric flowing. A good example of this is the line "The movement you need is on your shoulder" in "Hey Jude" which McCartney intended to change but was convinced by Lennon to keep.
 It is entirely possible that the phrase "Norwegian wood" has no meaning.
 The song itself has the sense of being a self-satire of boy-meets-girl tunes of the early Beatle days and its being on "Rubber Soul", which is essentially the first of the Psychedelic period albums, tends to support this.
 Then again, maybe the girl played the Hardinger fiddle and he burned that. We'll never know.
comment_99: this is about some girl trying to seduce him and hes just being oblivious and innocent, i luv this song...
comment_100:
OK..here's what I think for what it's worth:

"I once had a girl or should I say she once had me"

John thought that he had this girl's love or that she was attracted to him. The second part of the line is a play on words which John was really good at. She "had" him...he played a 'joke' on him, did some devious act. Like leading him on that she'd sleep with him when she never had any intention of doing so.

"...and I noticed there wasn't a chair"

I think this refers to that she wasn't interested in any sort of lasting relationship. She was transient/flight. She didn't put roots down in life or in relationships.

"I sat on her rug, biding my time, drinking her wine."

He was trying to act informal, not wanting to look 'pushy'. So he casually sit down on the rug, probably leaned back and sat drinking wine waiting until the appropriate moment to make the move to get her into bed for sex. (Sitting on the floor/rug back in the 1960's and 1970's was common amongst friends. Every weekend in the '70's I'd party with my musician friends and we'd all sit cross-legged on the floor with our guitars).

About sleeping in the bath. One of two things. It could be that he was drunk and the bathtub was a handy place to crawl off to and be cool in (so the 'hots' following a night of drinking weren't so bad) or he wants to show that he was deeply disappointed in how the night turned out and that the bath represented an empty lonely cold place to have to be.

"So, I light up a fire...." 
OK...confession time. I was 9 years old when the Beatles were on Ed Sullivan in 1964. STOP SNICKERING :)    In my childish naivity I first thought that he simply built a fire in the fireplace to warm up in the cold morning (for some reason I pictured her place as a log cabin type place made out of logs). But now I really do think that he either burnt up what little furniture she had or set fire to the whole place.

First he admires the Norwegian wood as something nice to look at, when he still thinks that he has a chance with her. But in the morning faced with disappointment he now sees the wood in it's beauty as it burns.

Oh, BTW. I'm not discounting the thought that Norwegian Wood is a type of marijuana. But from experience. Back then we didn't that many choices as to types of marijuana. We were darned lucky if a bit of Acapulco Gold came our way. Next on the list was just some anonymous stuff from Mexico. But mostly, it was locally grown yucky stuff without much bang and hot as a blowtorch. But the Beatles being who they were probably could get some more exotic weed than some poor Midwestern teens could !

comment_114: So I think we've more or less established that this song revolves around one of John's affairs while still married to Cynthia. From my analysis of the last verse, I think the most revealing line is "This bird has flown." To be metaphorical, I would say the bird is the relationship, and its flight was the essence of its existence. Having flown, it has seen from great heights the awe-inspiring landscapes and natural beauties of this world--all from a seemingly safe and isolated position. But upon landing, the bird terminates its existence under the weight of a gravitational force it can no longer defy; its essence disintegrating into the organic elements that initially composed it. And, who knows? maybe the bird landed on some indistinct tree in Norway which concurrently fell victim to a forest fire.
comment_115:
It's about John having an affair.

He thinks he has this girl (she's in love with him / will do whatever he wants) but she is infact just leading him on.  

The "sit anywhere / there wasn't a chair" & "its time for bed / work in the morning / slept in the bath" lines are both telling us the same thing - that she was leading him on with suggestion, and then dropping him and leaving him alone again.

When he wakes up (in the bath haha) this girl has left him there, so, feeling pissed off, he sets the place on fire.  Walking out quite smugly thinking "isn't it good, norweigian wood?" (burns well).

The setting on fire bit is mentioned in Paul's authorised biography "Many years from now".  If you haven't read it, I strongly suggest you do!  Great book

comment_122:
Ok, this is my first posting, so don't get too brutal with me.
First off, it's a song. His wife of the time wouldn't be a consideration. It's not written in "Code".
Second, these guys were always giving the media a ride; so what they say isn't trustworthy (Ya, Lucy In The Sky wasn't about an acid trip...).
On to the song:
What it's about is getting high and getting laid.
"I once had a girl, or should I say she once had me"
Reflective. "Once" could mean a one-timer, or maybe not. But he "HAD" her, or she "HAD" him. Not hung with, or wanted. Had. End of story.
"She showed me her room. Isn't it good? Norwegian Wood."
Great line. Hmmm, listener thinks I'm talking about furniture...
"She asked me to stay" means I got lucky. "Told me to sit anywhere. So I looked around and I noticed there wasn't a chair"
This is built into the song craftily to let you, the listener know that it ain't furniture he was talking about, 'cause there ain't none!
"She told me she worked in the morning" is post coital conversation.
"I crawled off to sleep in the bath"? That damn rug wasn't cutting it. Oh ya, "crawled"? He was WASTED.
Woke up, got outa bed...
Sorry, wrong song.
Woke up, she'd gone to work, got into her stash and reiterated the quality of the stuff.
comment_123: Trowheels - great theory - aside from the fact that the song was written in January 1965 and John met yoko in November 1966 (articles.absoluteelsewhere.net/Articles/…)and Rubber Soul came out in 1965.
comment_124: Rubber Soul is one of my all-time favorite albums. I have to say that I never thought the "I lit the fire" line implies the singer literally set a fire. To me this song goes like this: The singer (John, who admitted to feeling very insecure and lost at this time in the Beatles career) goes home with the girl, assuming there will be sex. When she alludes to having to work in the morning and laughs, that is a clear signal that there will be no sex. My interpretation of the norwegian wood phrase is that the singer has a case of "blue balls", Norway being a cold country and wood a reference to an erection. The "I lit the fire" line to me either means that he masturbates to relieve his "norwegian wood", or that he is blaming himself for getting aroused over a girl who didn't want him.
comment_125:
I've always felt that the song revolves around a one-night encounter ("she showed me her room" and "i look around and I noticed...." both imply that the singer in unfamiliar with her apartment).

But ultimately I believe the song revolves around the mind games the lady is playing with the singer. 
*"or should I say she once had me"--suggests to me that the singer realied after-the-fact that the lady truly had the psychological upper-hand the entire encounter
*The lady invites the singer to sit anywhere, even though there is nowhere to actually sit.
*They drink wine and talk until 2am, certainly suggestive of leading up to sex
*"she told me she worked in the morning and started to laugh"--though it's not found in the lyrics, this particular lines seems to be in responce to the singer's suggesting/implication of sex. The "laugh"ing part was probably even more demoralizing for our assuming singer.
*"I was alone, this bird had flown"--the singer's ultimate realization of failure/isolation/rejection

I am also a VERY FIRM believer that our singer did indeed light a fire lady's apartment as his ultimate revenge for the lady leading him on the entire previous night. The first time the line "Isn't it good, Norweigen Wood" is sung, I believe it's from the lady's perspective. She is showing the singer around her apartment and is boasting about her Norweigen Wood furniture, so in this context the lyrical line seems almost boastful and condescending (which adheres to my "mind games" theory". However, the second time to lyric is sung (the final line), it's from the singer's perspective. He woke up alone and humiliated and decided to burn down her cherished furniture and ironically repeats the line "isn't it good, norweigen wood", in an entirely different and chilling context. It's as though the singer feels very emotionally hurt by the lady and realized that she manipulated him the only night, so he some-what childishly burns her furniture on his way out the door.

The song is truly amazing. One of the most perfect Beatles song recorded. Lyrically, Vocally, Instrumentally....
comment_126:
The lyrics of this song are actually pretty clear. This is about a homosexual encounter. Lennon was famous for his word play and double meanings, and his will to shock. The banality of this encounter in a heterosexual sense is hardly something that would inspire him to write a song (I mean how many more exciting sexual encounters did The Beatles have in the glory days!!!!). As a homosexual encounter however the lyrics take on a whole new meaning. 
I once had a girl, or should I say she once had me - a reference to who is giving and who is getting!
Norwegian Wood also is rather more pornographic than it initially seems, as is the "she told me to sit anywhere, so I looked around and I noticed there wasnt a chair" just Norwegian Wood to sit on apparently. Sitting on a rug, is a clear reference to pubic hair.
Remember that Beatles manager Brian Epstein was actively involved in gay London at the time, and as a close friend of Lennon it shouldnt be surprising that he would write about these kinds of things in his songs. Similar references appear in other songs, eg I am the Walrus "boy youve been a naughty girl you let your knickers down", knickers being gay slang for a partner or boyfriend at that time. Note also the substitution of boy and girl here, similar to the gender-swapping reference in Norwegian Wood.
Lennons genius at work!
comment_127: Just to clear it up, "bird" in Liverpool is slang for a girl. And yes I am a scouser!
comment_128: He makes a fire probably with peat or coal? Haha, is that bit in the lost verse that was never released? Did this encounter take place in a cave? Just read the words everybody, it is indeed a simple song, and glaringly obvious what it means unless you suffer from sexual hang ups!

a girl played him, he never really had her though she had him.

she offered him to stay, but he realized that their wasn't really any room in her life for him to stay a while. maybe a temporary fix.

"I sat on a rug, biding my time
Drinking her wine"
so he held onto her as he could, soaking in her lies and sweet words.

"We talked until two, and then she said:
"It's time for bed,""
they continued this for a while until she said it was time to give it a rest.

"She told me she worked in the morning and started to laugh
I told her I didn't, and crawled off to sleep in the bath"
she had other plans not involving him, so he ashamedly waited for her within reach with hopes that she'd be back soon enough.

"And when I awoke, I was alone
This bird has flown"

comment_138:
I once had a girl
Or should I say she once had me
She showed me her room
Isn't it good Norwegian wood?

In the first line I think he's saying that she has a hold on him or is teasing him.
Then he says that her room is decorated with Norwegian wood (a popular choice at the time)

She asked me to stay
And she told me to sit anywhere
So I looked around
And I noticed there wasn't a chair

Reiterating the fact that she was very much in charge as he was sitting on the floor for her.

I sat on a rug biding my time
Drinking her wine
We talked until two and then she said
"It's time for bed"

Obviously he thought that the rug was a temporary spot as he thought she was willing to have sex. 

She told me she worked
In the morning and started to laugh
I told her I didn't
And crawled off to sleep in the bath

Making it clear she meant sleep rather than sex and maybe laughing at him because he god the wrong idea.
He then sleeps in the bath, highlighting that he wasn't getting anything from her.

And when I awoke I was alone
This bird had flown
So I lit a fire
Isn't it good Norwegian wood?

Saying that he woke up and she had left, a 'failed' one night stand
He set fire to her room as shown through the repetition of the line 'isn't it good, Norwegian wood' as it was the same observation he made when looking at her room decor in the first place.

Just my interpretation :)
comment_139: Ok, let me admit up front that in the Barry Miles book on McCartney, Paul said he told John to finish up the song by burning the place down for revenge.  But I think John is more clever than that.  John loved word play and double meanings, Come Together with the orgasm lead out, the double meaning of please in Please Please Me, It Won't Be Long (Till I Belong), Happiness is a Warm Gun, Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds (yes, Lennon said he didn't know, but I don't believe him, that's something he would have picked up on immediately), the three puns in Because.  Norwegian Wood has been established as cheap pine wood for furniture or panelling on the walls and was trendy at the time, apparently.  Lennon gets invited to this woman's apartment that has cheap pine wood and he believes they are going to have sex.  But at two o'clock she tells him that is not going to happen and she has to work the next day.  He sleeps in the bath.  When he wakes up, she has already left to work.  The last line can be interpreted as following Paul's advice.  But I think he lights a sexual fire in the bathtub and masturbates, and the last line of Isn't it good Norwegian Wood compares cheap masturbation sex with cheap wood paneling, thus giving Norwegian Wood a double meaning.
comment_140:
This song is extremely frustrated.

What I mean by this is that is it essentially about being led on--yes, perhaps John intended it to take on a more sexual aspect, but either way it is true. The first sentence implies how they had interest in each other, but his was definitely more. She revealed a lot to him, including Norwegian wood. Norwegian wood is cheap wood, so right from the get-go it is revealed that whatever she felt for him was weaker than he presumed.

She had some interest in getting to know him, but it was not as much as he thought. However, he waited because she did offer him niceties. It's almost funny how relevant John was to the modern world and how people often stay up late talking and then simply go to bed like it was not a big deal. 

The girl had other obligations the next day and thought it was all good fun that they had been talking. But the speaker was still willing to wait up for her and sacrifice his own priorities. He does not make a move on her (sexual or otherwise) because she has just wrecked their late-night conversation by saying how she has "work" the next day.

When he woke up the next morning, she had moved on. The bird had flown and the speaker realizes he's too late (I say speaker out of respect but I have a feeling John was writing about himself). He's angry and lights a fire symbolically to the weak wood.

It astounds me how much pain and literary technique John uses in every song he writes. I feel like he understands me and my own similar experiences and it means the world to me. I wish we could have known each other because I feel like I could have understood him as well.
comment_141:
When I first heard the first line, "I once had a girl or should I say she once had me", I thought that meant he had the girl as a girlfriend, but then waxed kind of egotistical and said she had him as a boyfriend. 

But then I realized that the implication was that she no longer did, which meant he'd left her for some reason, and was about to explain why - so it wasn't just an egotistical remark. 

So then she leads him on and then leaves him high and dry, and then in the morning when he realizes what's happened, he burned her norwegian wood as an act of revenge. "So, I a lit a fire - isn't it good norwegian wood." 

It was clearly intended as a cheeky remark; it could have meant that he lit a fire in the fireplace and enjoyed the comfy feel of her place while waiting for her to return or something, but instead obviously meant that he burned her norwegian wood - but it wasn't initially clear to me whether he was burning some of her wood in the fireplace or if he burned her whole place. But the song doesn't mention a fireplace and the thing in the song which was made of norwegian wood was her room. "She showed me her room, wasn't it good, norwegian wood." So my guess was that he meant that he burned her room, which essentially meant burning the whole place down. That would turn the song into a sort of brief, simple, sing-songy snippet of prose that ends up packing quite a wallop which is a common sort of thing, and certainly seemed in character for the Beatles, so, that seemed like the mostly likely interpretation to me.

By the end it seemed that they didn't have sex, which made me question whether or not they were actually boyfriend and girlfriend, which cast doubt on my understanding of the first line. So it was a mystery to me what it meant until I read the explanation provided by Docent, on this page. The idea that "had" in "I once had a girl" referred to deceiving or tricking someone is pretty anathematic to me and would be another in a fairly long list of similar horrors that would cause me to be rather put off by likes of the Beatles, even if I enjoy their music. I would be virtually burned at the stake by a crowd of millions for admitting to such, but I've never been a conformist. 

But docent's quotes don't actually explain what "had" meant. I think I'd prefer to think that it wasn't so much about deceiving or tricking as it was about simply being in a relationship. Maybe they hadn't had sex yet, but had been fairly clearly building up to it.

The song seems like a kind of morbidly fascinating comment on philandering. The picture I get is of a sincere fellow who is wandering a bit from his main squeeze because he fairly desperately needs more, emotionally and physically, than he's getting, and thinks maybe he's found it in this new person, but it turns out she was just intent upon punishing him for philandering. So he unleashes his completely overwhelming bitter wrath upon her for appointing herself judge and jury over him and making him think she liked him and wanted him when she really didn't.

comment_144: John is using the same songwriting trick that Bob Dylan used on "Just Like a Woman". The line "We married/She's my friend" actually refers to two different women. John similarly writes "She said that she worked in the morning and started to laugh/ I told her I didn't and crawled off to sleep in the bath". Again the first line refers to the woman in the song the second to wife Cynthia.
